issueDTO.title: [RFE] Add support for client side validation for daemon-config
issueDTO.description:
https://github.com/inspektor-gadget/inspektor-gadget/issues/3168 added support for `daemon-config` but currently we don't support any client-side validation. In helm-charts we are using https://github.com/inspektor-gadget/inspektor-gadget/blob/main/charts/gadget/values.schema.json to perform early validations, similar approach can be used with `daemon-config`.

## Ideal Situation:

```yaml
# daemon-config.yaml
hookMode: foo
```

```
$ kubectl gadget deploy --daemon-config=daemon-config.yaml
Error: invalid argument "foo" for --hook-mode=[auto,crio,podinformer,nri,fanotify+ebpf]
```

summary.main:
Currently, daemon-config does not support client-side validation. It would be ideal to add support similar to helm-charts' https://github.com/inspektor-gadget/inspektor-gadget/blob/main/charts/gadget/values.schema.json. This would allow for early validation of daemon-config. For example, the following YAML configuration would result in an error:

```yaml
# daemon-config.yaml
hookMode: foo
```

```
$ kubectl gadget deploy --daemon-config=daemon-config.yaml
Error: invalid argument "foo" for --hook-mode=[auto,crio,podinformer,nri,fanotify+ebpf]
```

issueDTO.title: Don't create tool manifests in a .config subfolder by default
issueDTO.description:
A tool manifest file (dotnet-tools.json) can either be directly in the folder it applies to, or it can be in a `.config` subfolder.  The idea behind this was to group multiple configuration files in the `.config` folder in order to avoid cluttering the repo root.

However, we never ended up adding any other files to the .config subfolder.  So now we'd like to simplify local tools by putting the manifest file directly into the folder it applies to.

This will involve updating the tool-manifest template, as well as the code in the .NET CLI that creates the manifest if necessary.

Documentation, such as [this page](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/local-tools-how-to-use), should also be updated.

summary.otherNotes: The idea behind this was to group multiple configuration files in the .config folder in order to avoid cluttering the repo root.

issueDTO.title: [BUG] Mobile UI: Subscribe Form Layout Issue on Small Screens
issueDTO.description: ## Bug Report Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks! ### 1. Minimal reproduce step (Required) 1. Open https://www.kcl-lang.io/ on a mobile device (or resize your browser window to a mobile viewport width). 2. Scroll down to the "Subscribe to Newsletter" section. ### 2. What did you expect to see? (Required) The email input field and the "SUBSCRIBE" button should ideally be horizontally aligned, or at least optimized for a tidier and more integrated appearance on mobile screens. ### 3. What did you see instead (Required) The email input field and the "SUBSCRIBE" button are currently displayed vertically (one above the other), resulting in an untidy and less integrated appearance on mobile devices. **Screenshots:** **Current Mobile Layout:** *Description:* Shows the input field and button stacked vertically. ### 4. What is your KCL components version? (Required) N/A. This issue pertains to the User Interface (UI) of the `kcl-lang.io` website on mobile, not to a KCL component or runtime. --- ### Additional Information I have a local fix that adjusts the CSS/layout of the subscribe form to align the email input field and the "SUBSCRIBE" button horizontally on mobile viewports. This change significantly improves the form's appearance and responsiveness. **Screenshot of Proposed Layout (Local Fix Example):** *Description:* Shows the input field and button horizontally aligned, demonstrating a cleaner look. I am ready to open a Pull Request (PR) with the proposed changes if this improvement is a good fit for the project. Please let me know if you would like me to proceed with a PR. Thank you for your consideration.
comments: Good Catch! PRs welcome! Thank you! ♥

issueDTO.title: Rework docstrings to have consistent style
issueDTO.description:
It would be great to be consistent with the style of the existing docstrings, i.e. start the sentence with a verb for "brief". For example, I would put it here

```cpp
/**
 * @brief Publish the state of the controller manager.
 * 
 * The state includes the list of controllers and the list of hardware interfaces along with their states.
 */
```

However, I realize that we have already different docstring styles in this file. An example of another style is:

```cpp
/// A method to register a callback to be called when the list is switched
/**
* \param[in] callback Callback to be called when the list is switched
*/
```

Is it intentional to have these different styles? @christophfroehlich

_Originally posted by @Maverobot in https://github.com/ros-controls/ros2_control/pull/2006#discussion_r1921631365_
comments:
Hello @christophfroehlich,

I have worked on this issue and submitted a PR: [#2087][(https://github.com/Vishwanathkarne/pull/2087) ](https://github.com/ros-controls/ros2_control/pull/2087#issue-2889722330).

- I have ensured a consistent docstring style across the codebase.
- Followed the suggested format with @brief starting with a verb.
- Standardized different styles to improve clarity and maintainability.

This is my 1st open-source contribution, and I would love your feedback! 
Let me know if any improvements are needed. 
Thanks for this opportunity!
@christophfroehlich @saikishor 

Regards,
Vishwanath Karne
@christophfroehlich Is he still assigned to this issue? On the Contributing page, it’s empty.
there was no response in the PR from @im23123v since March?

issueDTO.title: Improve test coverage of PID class
issueDTO.description:
## Background
The PID class is a base implementation for lots of controllers. Therefore, we should thrive for full test coverage

Having a look at the [coverage report](https://app.codecov.io/gh/ros-controls/control_toolbox/tree/ros2-master/control_toolbox), we see that some methods have no coverage, e.g., 

- `void PidROS::reset()`
- `void PidROS::reset(bool save_i_term)`
- `double PidROS::compute_command(double error, double error_dot, const rclcpp::Duration & dt)`
- `void PidROS::set_current_cmd(double cmd) { pid_.set_current_cmd(cmd); }`
- `double PidROS::get_current_cmd() { return pid_.get_current_cmd(); }`
- `void PidROS::print_values()`

and in general, we have little coverage in testing the input validations.

Improve that by additional tests/test-cases.

## Instructions
Hi, this is a `good-first-issue` issue. This means we've worked to make it more legible to people who either **haven't contributed to our codebase before, or even folks who haven't contributed to open source before**.

We're interested in helping you take the first step, and can answer questions and help you out along the way. Note that we're especially interested in contributions from underrepresented groups!

We know that creating a pull request is the biggest barrier for new contributors. This issue is for you 💝

If you have contributed before, **consider leaving this PR for someone new**, and looking through our general [bug](https://github.com/ros-controls/ros2_control/labels/bug) issues. Thanks!

### 🤔 What you will need to know.

Nothing. This issue is meant to welcome you to Open Source :) We are happy to walk you through the process.

### 📋 Step by Step

- [ ] 🙋 **Claim this issue**: Comment below. If someone else has claimed it, ask if they've opened a pull request already and if they're stuck -- maybe you can help them solve a problem or move it along!

issueDTO.title: [docs] Add node_selection_strategy to the Presto documentation
issueDTO.description:
Add documentation for `node_selection_strategy` to the Presto documentation. 

## Expected Behavior or Use Case
Documentation should be present. 

## Presto Component, Service, or Connector
Documentation. 


## Context
When reviewing #24193 I noticed that `node_selection_strategy` is mentioned in the doc for `query-data-cache-enabled-default` in [Presto C++ Features](https://github.com/prestodb/presto/blob/master/presto-docs/src/main/sphinx/presto_cpp/features.rst), but wasn't documented itself. 

Note: after this was opened, `node_selection_strategy` and `query-data-cache-enabled-default` were removed from `query-data-cache-enabled-default` in [Presto C++ Features](https://github.com/prestodb/presto/blob/master/presto-docs/src/main/sphinx/presto_cpp/features.rst). 

`node_selection_strategy` is mentioned in [Session Properties](https://prestodb.io/docs/current/connector/iceberg.html#session-properties) of the Iceberg Connector and in [Hive Changes](https://prestodb.io/docs/current/release/release-0.233.html#hive-changes) in the 0.233 Release Notes. 

_Add configuration property hive.node-selection-strategy to choose NodeSelectionStrategy. When SOFT_AFFINITY is selected, scheduler will make the best effort to request the same worker to fetch the same file._

`hive.node-selection-strategy` is mentioned in [Iceberg Connector](https://prestodb.io/docs/current/connector/iceberg.html), but is not mentioned in [Hive Connector.](https://prestodb.io/docs/current/connector/hive.html)

issueDTO.title: feat: Log all JSON schema validation errors in sinks/targets
issueDTO.description:
### Feature scope

Taps (catalog, state, stream maps, tests, etc.)

### Description

The default JSON schema validation implementation uses the `.validate()`[^1] method. This means that only _one_ schema validation failure is logged to the user:

https://github.com/meltano/sdk/blob/6638a908736d42887178f5645b913b9ec3aa662d/singer_sdk/sinks/core.py#L120-L123

It might be helpful to instead display all validation errors, and we could use the `.iter_errors()` method for that, raising an appropriate `InvalidRecord` exception.

[^1]: https://python-jsonschema.readthedocs.io/en/stable/validate/
comments: This has been marked as stale because it is unassigned, and has not had recent activity. It will be closed after 21 days if no further activity occurs. If this should never go stale, please add the `evergreen` label, or request that it be added.
Still relevant

issueDTO.title: Confusing ERROR tracing when not actually an error
issueDTO.description:
https://github.com/ludfjig/hyperlight/blob/31bfc5a2f54e88d29e29388ac0a908d25f97fc19/src/hyperlight_common/src/flatbuffer_wrappers/guest_error.rs#L199

causes any failures to be logged with ERROR level. However, we use this function unconditionally to check whether an error occured or not here https://github.com/ludfjig/hyperlight/blob/31bfc5a2f54e88d29e29388ac0a908d25f97fc19/src/hyperlight_host/src/func/guest_err.rs#L28

Thus the function returning an Err does not necessarily mean an actual error occured.

The issue can be reproduced by running for example `cargo run --package hyperlight-host --example logging` and observing the error logs related to "pop_buffer_into". (NOT the executioncancelledbyhost errors)

- The short term fix would be to remove the `instrument` macro on the functions that unconditionally return an error in the happy code path.
- The long term fix would be to change the way we check if an error occured.
comments: @ludfjig  I can look into this

> [@ludfjig](https://github.com/ludfjig) I can look into this

That would be awesome @myadav27

```terminal
$ RUST_LOG=error cargo run --example hello-world
   Compiling hyperlight-host v0.6.1 (/home/dblnz/workspace/msft/hyperlight/src/hyperlight_host)
    Finished `dev` profile [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 7.00s
     Running `target/debug/examples/hello-world`
Hello, World! I am executing inside of a VM :)
[2025-06-18T16:39:09Z ERROR hyperlight_common::flatbuffer_wrappers::guest_error] error=Error while reading GuestError: Unaligned { position: 23, unaligned_type: "u64", error_trace: ErrorTrace([TableField { field_name: "code", position: 23 }]) }
[2025-06-18T16:39:09Z ERROR hyperlight_host::mem::shared_mem] error=Error("pop_buffer_into: failed to convert buffer to hyperlight_common::flatbuffer_wrappers::guest_error::GuestError")
[2025-06-18T16:39:09Z ERROR hyperlight_host::mem::mgr] error=Error("pop_buffer_into: failed to convert buffer to hyperlight_common::flatbuffer_wrappers::guest_error::GuestError")
```
#662 PR is a short term fix. We should not rely on this "trying to deserialize an error" for error handling. Leaving this open so we can address this properly in the future.

repository.description: Hyperlight is a lightweight Virtual Machine Manager (VMM) designed to be embedded within applications. It enables safe execution of untrusted code within micro virtual machines with very low latency and minimal overhead.
repository.name: hyperlight

summary.main:
Confusing ERROR tracing when not actually an error. Causes any failures to be logged with ERROR level. However, we use this function unconditionally to check whether an error occurred or not here https://github.com/ludfjig/hyperlight/blob/31bfc5a2f54e88d29e29388ac0a908d25f97fc19/src/hyperlight_host/src/func/guest_err.rs#L28

Thus the function returning an Err does not necessarily mean an actual error occurred.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue can be reproduced by running for example `cargo run --package hyperlight-host --example logging` and observing the error logs related to "pop_buffer_into". (NOT the executioncancelledbyhost errors)
summary.attemptedFixes:
The short term fix would be to remove the `instrument` macro on the functions that unconditionally return an error in the happy code path.
The long term fix would be to change the way we check if an error occurred.
summary.otherNotes: PR is a short term fix. We should not rely on this "trying to deserialize an error" for error handling. Leaving this open so we can address this properly in the future.

issueDTO.title: Unhelpful WinAppSdk not installed error dialog
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the bug

The error dialog displayed when starting a framework dependant unpackaged app when the minimum WinAppSdk isn't installed doesn't give enough info to allow the user to install one.

![Screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28826959/198292399-5315cc74-c220-4ba2-b6b8-f872c9a81c54.png)

The name and package version of the framework package doesn't identify a WinAppSdk release.

### Steps to reproduce the bug

As above

### Expected behavior

It should at least identify the minimum WinAppSdk version and preferably contain an htlm link to a specific version download, rather than the generic all versions web page.


### Screenshots

_No response_

### NuGet package version

1.2.220930.4-preview2

### Packaging type

Unpackaged

### Windows version

Windows 11 version 21H2 (22000)

### IDE

Visual Studio 2022

### Additional context

_No response_
comments:
>The name and package version of the framework package doesn't identify a WinAppSdk release.

Depends how you define 'release'. We show "1.1". You meant e.g. "1.1.9".

>It should at least identify the minimum WinAppSdk version and preferably contain an htlm link to a specific version download, rather than the generic all versions web page.

Nice ask.

When you hit YES on that dialog we ShellExecute() the download page.

We could e.g. ShellExecute("https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/apps/windows-app-sdk/downloads#windows-app-sdk-11"). That would take you to major.minor release section of the download page. That would require those sections' URLs to be long-term stable URLs. If not, alternative URLs are needed.

@kythant @gabbybilka @MikeHillberg are those URLs long-term stable? If not is there a long-term stable alternative? If not could we make that?

This issue can be reproduced using unpackaged sample apps from the [WindowsAppSDK-Samples](https://github.com/microsoft/WindowsAppSDK-Samples/tree/release/experimental/Samples/Unpackaged) repository.
🛠️ Resolution Guidance
The error dialog currently directs users to the latest Windows App SDK downloads page, rather than the specific version required by the application, which can lead to confusion—especially when older versions are hosted separately.
✅ Expected Behavior
Ensure the error dialog redirects users to atleast the correct major/minor version of the required installer.
🔗 Linking Strategy
	• Collaborate with the Docs team to determine whether redirection links can be hosted entirely on the docs site. For example, link to version 1.7 could initially point to the main downloads page and later redirect to the archive page. Or, whether we need to create stable links for each version
🧩 Code Changes
	• Confirm that the correct major and minor version numbers are accessible—or can be made accessible—in code at the point where the error dialog is invoked (see [Initialize_OnError_ShowUI](https://github.com/microsoft/WindowsAppSDK/blob/5ce1f09f8ed314dd647c12be1d910ef894645168/dev/Deployment/DeploymentManager.cpp#L661) and [MddBootstrapInitialize_ShowUI_OnNoMatch](https://github.com/microsoft/WindowsAppSDK/blob/5ce1f09f8ed314dd647c12be1d910ef894645168/dev/WindowsAppRuntime_BootstrapDLL/MddBootstrap.cpp#L1153))
	• Construct a version-specific URL using the major and minor version numbers and pass it to the ShellExecute call.
🔮 Future-Proofing
	• Consider fallback behavior if a version-specific link is unavailable (low priority).

repository.description: The Windows App SDK empowers all Windows desktop apps with modern Windows UI, APIs, and platform features, including back-compat support, shipped via NuGet.
repository.name: WindowsAppSDK

summary.main: The error dialog displayed when starting a framework dependant unpackaged app when the minimum WinAppSdk isn't installed doesn't give enough info to allow the user to install one.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The name and package version of the framework package doesn't identify a WinAppSdk release.
summary.attemptedFixes:
The error dialog currently directs users to the latest Windows App SDK downloads page, rather than the specific version required by the application. The expected behavior is to ensure the error dialog redirects users to at least the correct major/minor version of the required installer.

Code Changes:
	• Confirm that the correct major and minor version numbers are accessible—or can be made accessible—in code at the point where the error dialog is invoked.
	• Construct a version-specific URL using the major and minor version numbers and pass it to the ShellExecute call.

Future-Proofing:
	• Consider fallback behavior if a version-specific link is unavailable (low priority).
summary.otherNotes: The issue can be reproduced using unpackaged sample apps from the WindowsAppSDK-Samples repository.

issueDTO.title: feature: expand regular testing
issueDTO.description:
### Feature Description

The current testing only exercises one deployment configuration: three new `kind` clusters, with fresh new KubeFlex ControlPlanes for WDS and ITS. We think that KubeStellar works in more configurations, and they should be tested.

- Things other than `kind` providing Kubernetes clusters.
- The WDS and/or ITS role played by the hosting cluster.
- The WDS and/or ITS role played by some other pre-existing cluster.
- One new ControlPlane playing both ITS and WDS roles.


### Proposed Solution

Do something. Without expanding the gating CI tests too much (note: I am not asserting exactly how much is too much).

### Rule name

lint/correctness/noUnusedImports

### Playground link

https://biomejs.dev/playground/?code=aQBtAHAAbwByAHQAIAB0AHkAcABlACAAewB9ACAAZgByAG8AbQAgACcAQABtAHUAaQAvAHgALQBkAGEAdABhAC0AZwByAGkAZAAvAHQAaABlAG0AZQBBAHUAZwBtAGUAbgB0AGEAdABpAG8AbgAnADsA

### Expected result

For certain libraries like MUI, we have imports purely for type augmentation like this:

```ts
import type {} from '@mui/lab/themeAugmentation';
```

We use `import type {}` so that it will only utilize the type information and nothing else during bundling.

In Biome v1 there was no error, but Biome v2 triggers an error for `lint/correctness/noUnusedImports` and the fixer actually removes the statement which causes other issues. 

### Code of Conduct

- [x] I agree to follow Biome's Code of Conduct
comments:
Type augmentation imports should be treated as an exception, because it's very difficult to understand whether they are doing something or it's a user error.

The reason why Biome v1 didn't trigger it, it's simply because we fixed a bunch of bugs. I believe we should document this as expection.

issueDTO.title: [Feature Request]: Support for PP-OCRv5's New Model Format (inference.json, inference.pdiparams, inference.yml)
issueDTO.description:
### Request Description

PaddleOCR recently updated the model format for PP-OCRv5 . The previous format used three files:

> inference.pdmodel
> 
> inference.pdiparams
> 
> inference.pdiparams.info

The new format now consists of:

> inference.json
> 
> inference.pdiparams
> 
> inference.yml

This change breaks compatibility with OpenVINO’s current PaddlePaddle model support, which expects the legacy file structure.
Could the OpenVINO team confirm if there are plans to:
Add support for the new PP-OCRv5 model format?
PP-OCRv5 is a state-of-the-art OCR model widely adopted in production deployments.
Users upgrading to PP-OCRv5 will be blocked from leveraging OpenVINO’s optimizations without format compatibility.

### Feature Use Case

_No response_

### Issue submission checklist

- [x] The feature request or improvement must be related to OpenVINO

issueDTO.title: Home Screen Icon support for Android and iOS
issueDTO.description:
**Technical improvement**
Add support for Home Screen icons (also known as web app manifest icons or PWA icons) for both Android and iOS platforms. This includes providing the necessary icon assets in required sizes and adding or updating the web app manifest and HTML meta tags so that users who add the site to their home screens will see a branded icon. The implementation should follow best practices for Progressive Web Apps (PWAs).

Expected outcome:
- When a user adds saythanks.io to their home screen on Android or iOS, a custom app icon should appear instead of a generic browser icon.
- All required icon sizes are provided and referenced correctly.
- Manifest and meta tags are validated for both platforms.

issueDTO.title: Output the number of failed transformations at the end of the `moco()` function
issueDTO.description:
In `sct_fmri_moco` and `sct_dmri_moco`, when the registration algorithm does not find a transformation between adjacent time points, it uses the previous transformation (closest in time). 

In this case, the transformation function returns `1`, which gets tracked in a list variable called `failed_transfo`:

https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/blob/cab82fd13425515a8568225dbe7fc003d9be2b1f/spinalcordtoolbox/moco.py#L765-L777

https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/blob/cab82fd13425515a8568225dbe7fc003d9be2b1f/spinalcordtoolbox/moco.py#L786-L787

https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/blob/cab82fd13425515a8568225dbe7fc003d9be2b1f/spinalcordtoolbox/moco.py#L588

https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/blob/cab82fd13425515a8568225dbe7fc003d9be2b1f/spinalcordtoolbox/moco.py#L613-L615

It would be relevant for the user, at the end of the process, to indicate how many transformations failed. (Since, while a failed transformation will emit a warning, this warning will be in the middle of processing which is easily missed.)

repository.description: Comprehensive and open-source library of analysis tools for MRI of the spinal cord.
repository.name: spinalcordtoolbox

summary.main: In the `sct_fmri_moco` and `sct_dmri_moco` functions, when the registration algorithm does not find a transformation between adjacent time points, it uses the previous transformation (closest in time). The transformation function returns `1`, which gets tracked in a list variable called `failed_transfo`. The issue is that the user is not informed about the number of failed transformations at the end of the process.

issueDTO.title: Fix naming discrepancy between owner_id and kinder_id in database schema
issueDTO.description:
## Description

Currently, there is a naming discrepancy in our database schema where we use `owner_id` instead of `kinder_id` in the implementation. This is inconsistent with our terminology where:

- **kindlers:** Project owners, partners, and members
- **kinders:** Project contributors and community participants

## Requirements

1. Update all instances in the database schema where `owner_id` is used instead of `kinder_id` to ensure consistency
2. Ensure the code references these fields correctly
3. Update any related documentation to reflect the correct naming conventions

## Related Issues
- #43 Project Table Schema and Relationships Epic

## Context
This issue was identified during a code integrity check on Epic #43. The discrepancy could lead to confusion and potential bugs if not addressed.

@AndlerRL
comments: Could I take on this issue?

Hello! I'm Sofi Barboza, member of Dojo Coding. I have experience with databases and Javascript, identifying and fixing bugs. I would like to contribute with this as it's a great opportunity for me to review my first issue. I'm so excited to apply my skills and learn a lot! 😊
Could I take on this issue?

Hi, I'm Josue Soto from the Dojo Coding community, graduate software engineer, I have 3 years of experience working in databases and IT industry.

**How I plan to solve it:**

- Analyze the database schema and all the relationships.
- Fix naming discrepancy between owner_id and kinder_id.
- Update all instances in the database.
- Update all related documentation to reflect the correct nomenclature conventions.
- Test the tables and verify that everything works correctly.
May I take this issue on?

Hi, I'd like to take this issue. I have experience handling schema consistency tasks and ensuring naming conventions are properly updated across database, code, and documentation. I’ll make sure all instances are corrected carefully to avoid any confusion or future bugs. Let me know if you'd like me to start with a quick PR!

I've already handled some tasks in #Supabase in this project. I'm confident I can deliver this on time. Let me handle it.

Have push access on a new branch, ready for signed commits and all other best practices.

Hi team,

I'd like to work on Issue #448 regarding the renaming of `owner_id` to `kinder_id` to align with KindFi's internal terminology and avoid confusion across the system.

Here’s how I plan to approach it:

### 1. Schema Refactor (Supabase)
- Identify all instances of `owner_id` across the Supabase schema (tables, relationships, foreign keys).
- Rename the columns to `kinder_id`, preserving existing constraints.
- Create a properly versioned SQL migration file using Supabase CLI and place it under `services/supabase/migrations/`.
- Validate database consistency after the rename through Supabase CLI and dashboard tools.

### 2. Backend Adjustments (`services/supabase`)
- Refactor all code references to `owner_id` across query logic, types, and service utilities.
- Ensure all affected endpoints and mutations behave as expected with the updated schema.

### 3. Frontend Integration (`apps/web`)
- Update Supabase queries, types, and hooks that reference `owner_id`.
- Refactor relevant components or forms handling project ownership or user metadata.
- Run and update any impacted unit tests or mocks accordingly.

### 4. Documentation
- Update schema diagrams, ERD references, and technical documentation under `docs/` to reflect the updated field naming and align with project terminology.

###  Deliverables
- Fully working PR with schema + code changes.
- A Supabase CLI-compatible SQL migration script.
- Clear changelog and commit breakdown.
- Optional: Schema diff or notes for internal dev reference.

**ETA:** I estimate 36–48 hours for full implementation, testing, and documentation updates.

Let me know if you'd like me to take it! 
Happy to help standardize and improve the DB structure.

issueDTO.title: [Enhancement] Histogram aggregation should initialize Ranges lazily
issueDTO.description:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe

Currently, optimized histogram aggregation using multi range traversal initialized `Ranges` with all buckets eagerly. While for individual request, memory implications are small, it can starting adding up across all requests on a node.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Given we process buckets one at a time, they can be initialized lazily avoiding unnecessary memory allocations. This should also allow to raise the number of buckets limit from 3k to 10k or more 

### Related component

_No response_

_No response_

issueDTO.title: `dolt checkout test0 test1` fails all if one is missing, but git checks out available ones
issueDTO.description:
When running `dolt checkout test0 test1`, if `test0` does not exist, `dolt` prevents `test1` from being checked out as well. In contrast, Git processes each path independently: if one path is missing, it checks out the others that are valid.

`test1` should be checked out, and only `test0` should cause an error/warning. For further clarification these two elements would be tables.

issueDTO.title: Replace supervisor with nodemon
issueDTO.description:
I'm developing a micro-services backend using Foal TS.

In the development environment, I use a "multiple console" runner. I launch every service at the same time. 

The problem is that when I run the Foal 4 projects, it never starts, I have to reboot manually the services until it starts working. And, also, it takes sometimes like 10 minutes.

In the next image: Metr is working, Coord, Cred, High, Iden, Logg, Stge and Stor are not working. Mail and Func are not FoalTS services, so please ignore them.

![image](https://github.com/FoalTS/foal/assets/5065981/7ca16e32-eddb-4fa0-88c6-c74addc71f45)

That is not what happens if I run all the Foal V2 projects.

In the next image: All services are working.

![image](https://github.com/FoalTS/foal/assets/5065981/61e6bfcc-9d42-4706-9417-ebaa3e3d38dc)

I'm sure the problem is Supervisor, because the problem was fixed after replacing it with another tool (a popular tool named `nodemon`).

https://www.npmjs.com/package/nodemon

This not only solves the problem, but also starts the project faster.

My new command for `npm run dev` is:

```json
{
"dev": "npm run build && concurrently -r \"tsc -p tsconfig.app.json -w\" \"nodemon --delay 2 -w ./build -w ./config -e js,json,yml ./build/index.js\"",
}
```
comments:
Which version of supervisor did you have in Foal 2 and in Foal 4?

Also, what was the command in `package.json` in Foal 2 and in Foal 4?

I was researching. Supervisor not only is less popular than Nodemon, also, is not mantained:

![image](https://github.com/FoalTS/foal/assets/5065981/1317aaee-5cb5-46ff-ab23-728287847332)

![image](https://github.com/FoalTS/foal/assets/5065981/9528cafa-1847-4678-99d3-e4ff879ab8f1)


Vs nodemon:

![image](https://github.com/FoalTS/foal/assets/5065981/289cda1f-bb71-48c7-89da-28bf22fc7df7)

![image](https://github.com/FoalTS/foal/assets/5065981/fc04aa9e-d7a5-4cea-bad6-a3b5beb1d51d)


Maybe replacing Supervisor is a good idea.

If you want, I can send you a pull request.

Out of curiosity, what operating system are you running?

The reasons why `supervisor` was chosen in the first place rather than `nodemon` were the following:
- It has 0 dependencies (and sub-dependencies) which has many advantages like a smaller size of the `node_modules` directory, fewer trouble to deal with when a sub-dependency suddenly breaks things in a minor version, and fewer security vulnerabilities to patch.
- And, at the time, when installing `nodemon`, a message was displayed in the terminal asking users to donate money/sponsors to the project, which sort of "polluted" the installation output.

But perhaps this is something that no longer applies:
- As you pointed out, `supervisor` seems no longer to be maintained, which could lead to problems in the future (unpatched vulnerabilities, new versions of Node not being supported).
- Installation of `nodemon` no longer displays a "money message".
- The output of `npm run dev` is more "beautiful" with `nodemon`.
- And `nodemon` starts the project faster (based on what you said).

(I don't think popularity is a good criterion for choice though.)

An alternative, which I hope will work one day, would be to use the native `node --watch` function. Unfortunately, the `--watch-path` option doesn't work on Linux at the moment.

Moving to `nodemon` seems to be an interesting choice then, **do you want to submit a PR?**

They are some stuff that should still work though:
- when a file config file in JSON or YAML is changed, the server should restart,
- when an error is thrown when the server start, the server should not be reloaded indefinitely,
- doc examples with gRPC and GraphQL should be updated and still work.

@lcnvdl if you take this one, I'd recommend to start with a completely new fork and "checkouts" your feature branch from `v4-5-0`. The dependency system has been updated in this branch and it will be easier to run `npm install nodemon` and `npm uninstall supervisor` in `@foal/examples`.

Thank you for your answer.

> Out of curiosity, what operating system are you running?

Windows 11

> 
> The reasons why `supervisor` was chosen in the first place rather than `nodemon` were the following:
> 
> * It has 0 dependencies (and sub-dependencies) which has many advantages like a smaller size of the `node_modules` directory, fewer trouble to deal with when a sub-dependency suddenly breaks things in a minor version, and fewer security vulnerabilities to patch.

I understand your reasons.

> * And, at the time, when installing `nodemon`, a message was displayed in the terminal asking users to donate money/sponsors to the project, which sort of "polluted" the installation output.
> 
> But perhaps this is something that no longer applies:
> 
> * As you pointed out, `supervisor` seems no longer to be maintained, which could lead to problems in the future (unpatched vulnerabilities, new versions of Node not being supported).
> * Installation of `nodemon` no longer displays a "money message".
> * The output of `npm run dev` is more "beautiful" with `nodemon`.
> * And `nodemon` starts the project faster (based on what you said).
> 
> (I don't think popularity is a good criterion for choice though.)
> 
> An alternative, which I hope will work one day, would be to use the native `node --watch` function. Unfortunately, the `--watch-path` option doesn't work on Linux at the moment.
> 
> Moving to `nodemon` seems to be an interesting choice then, **do you want to submit a PR?**

Sure!

> 
> They are some stuff that should still work though:
> 
> * when a file config file in JSON or YAML is changed, the server should restart,

Ok

> * when an error is thrown when the server start, the server should not be reloaded indefinitely,

Ok

> * doc examples with gRPC and GraphQL should be updated and still work.

Ok, I never tried that examples, but I will run them before and after the change, in order to get the same results.

> I'd recommend to start with a completely new fork and "checkouts" your feature branch from

Sure! Thanks for the information

Hello,

and why not use PM2 which allows you to do it in DEV or PROD mode...?

Thanks
PM2 presents itself as a "a production process manager for Node.js/Bun applications with a built-in load balancer." It doesn't seem to me to be the most appropriate solution in this case.
Okay i changed to nodemon

comments:
# KubeFlex Installation Guide

This guide provides detailed instructions for installing KubeFlex, including prerequisites for Windows users.

## Prerequisites

Before installing KubeFlex, ensure that you have the necessary tools and permissions on your system. For Windows users, you need to install `sudo` to execute commands with elevated privileges. Here are the steps to install `sudo` on Windows:

### Installing `sudo` on Windows

1. **Using Chocolatey:**
   - If you don't have Chocolatey installed, you can install it by following the instructions on the [Chocolatey website](https://chocolatey.org/install).
   - Once Chocolatey is installed, open a command prompt as an administrator and run:
     ```bash
     choco install gsudo
     ```

2. **Using Scoop:**
   - If you don't have Scoop installed, you can install it by following the instructions on the [Scoop website](https://scoop.sh/).
   - Once Scoop is installed, open a command prompt as an administrator and run:
     ```bash
     scoop install gsudo
     ```

3. **Using WinGet:**
   - If you don't have WinGet installed, you can install it by following the instructions on the [WinGet website](https://github.com/microsoft/winget-cli).
   - Once WinGet is installed, open a command prompt as an administrator and run:
     ```bash
     winget install gerardog.gsudo
     ```

## Installation Instructions for KubeFlex

1. **Download the KubeFlex CLI:**
   - Download the latest KubeFlex CLI binary release for your OS/Architecture from the [release page](https://github.com/kubestellar/kubeflex/releases) and copy it to `/usr/local/bin` or another location in your `$PATH`.

   For example, on Linux amd64:
   ```bash
   OS_ARCH=linux_amd64
   LATEST_RELEASE_URL=\$(curl -H "Accept: application/vnd.github.v3+json" https://api.github.com/repos/kubestellar/kubeflex/releases/latest | jq -r '.assets[] | select(.name | contains("linux_amd64")) | .browser_download_url')
   sudo install -o root -g root -m 0755 <(curl -L \$LATEST_RELEASE_URL) /usr/local/bin/kfle


2.**Alternative Installation Command:**
You can also use the following command, which will automatically detect the host OS type and architecture:

```
sudo bash <(curl -s https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kubestellar/kubeflex/main/scripts/install-kubeflex.sh) --ensure-folder /usr/local/bin

```

@Krishna-mishra-26 ty for your help here. This document would probably work best as a PR in the KubeFlex documentation. @pdettori where would you like this to be placed in source?  Once the PR is created, maintainers can make suggestions for changes and updates.

issueDTO.description:
# Issue

TSLint is (unfortunately) no longer maintained and framework linting should be migrated to ESLint.

This was done four years ago in [this PR](https://github.com/FoalTS/foal/pull/561) for projects generated with Foal. This means that, when executing the `createapp` command, new projects generated with this command use ESLint.

But the framework monorepo itself has not yet been migrated to ESLint. This is a technical debt that should be resolved.

# Guidelines

- ~If [this PR](https://github.com/FoalTS/foal/pull/1260), which updates the way dependencies are managed in monorepo, has not yet been merged, the new branch should be created from `v4-5-0`. Otherwise, it should be created from `master`. Not only will this facilitate the migration to ESLint, it will also avoid the need for additional work later on to manage ESLint dependencies with the new dependency system.~
- Migration to ESLint should not change the style of the framework code (we don't want thousands of line changes to commit). A lot of work had been done at the time in [this PR](https://github.com/FoalTS/foal/pull/561) to make ESLint rules consistent with TSLint rules. There's probably a lot to be learned from this PR.
- When opening the framework repository with VSCode with the ESLint plugin enabled, VSCode should correctly highlight ESLint errors and correct them when saving (if the plugin is configurer to do so).

# Notes

- There *might* be useful information [here](https://typescript-eslint.io/getting-started/typed-linting/monorepos/).
- The files `packages/cli/src/generate/specs/app/.eslintrc.js` and `packages/cli/src/generate/templates/app/.eslintrc.js` used by `foal createapp` to generate new projects may cause problems.

issueDTO.title: Automate localizations
issueDTO.description:
1.8+ has a Chinese localization. We may have others contributed in the future. It would be useful to provide some type of automation around identifying:

1. what en.yml strings do not have a corresponding localization for zh-CN.yml (what keys in en.yml do not exist in zh-CN.yml)
1. what keys in zh-CN.yml do not exist in en.yml - these would be old keys in zh-CN.yml that may need removed, or they are misspelled keys
1. if an en.yml string gets updated/modified, to flag which strings in zh-CN.yml need updated (this requires a clever git blame to determine the line number in the YAML file where a key starts and ensure the commit date of zh-CN.yml for a given key is greater than the commit date for the same key in en.yml. if en.yml is later that indicates that for this key the translation has been updated or modified and may need to be updated or modified for zh-CN. NOTE: a problem with this is if there is a false positive... like we fix a typo in the English or word it better but the Chinese is good and needs no update.. we could figure that out later). Could use https://www.rubydoc.info/github/libgit2/rugged/Rugged/Blame for this
1. what strings in the application have not be internationalized (these strings are hardcoded)

There are many tools and approaches for this, but we want to keep deployment simple. The yaml files mean the translations stay with the code which is nice. Could probably use `for_line`. This also might encourage us to avoid multi-line strings in the locale files.

Maybe a rake task is sufficient to start.

Also worth searching for existing tools that might assist with this as an alternative to writing our own.

┆Issue is synchronized with this [Asana task](https://app.asana.com/0/1202821104799596/1204178484951391) by [Unito](https://www.unito.io)
comments:
Take a look at "Translation management systems" (TMS). There are also tools like https://github.com/pejuko/i18n-translators-tools to convert the default Rails yaml into other formats for easier translation. We could also consider future versions of OnDemand using gettext. gettext doesn't use keys like the Rails yaml does, and just takes the full sentence and provides a translation for it. Most TMS support this out of the box, though there may also be examples of TMS projects that work with the Rails yaml formats. Another benefit of the gettext PO format is that its language/framework independent so if at some point we drop Rails or still have a mixture of Rails and other language/framework for apps in OnDemand, or want to translate error strings in Apache and/or NGINX as well, we can handle all of that in an language independent way.

Examples: http://pootle.translatehouse.org/, http://zanata.org/ (RedHat product with free open source project support)

Search for "open source translation management systems" to see many options.

Still thinking about this. Seems we can use https://github.com/glebm/i18n-tasks and some translation service like openapi or google to generate files. Then it's just a matter of making the pull request like we do for the chagnelog or dependencies.
Initial PR does not address full scope of this issue, reopening

issueDTO.title: Do not overwrite database on older versions
issueDTO.description:
## Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

#588 introduced a new behaviour that invalidates an existing database if its version does not match with the current TQEC version. 

If a database is out-of-date, it is invalidated and overwritten without warning. Users *might* want to keep the database somewhere, so it would be nice to rename the old, out-of-date, database before overwriting it, leaving the possibility to re-use it with an older version of TQEC.

## Describe the solution you'd like

Renaming the database instead of overwriting it.

repository.description: Design automation software tools for Topological Quantum Error Correction
repository.name: tqec

summary.main: The main issue is that the database is overwritten without warning when its version does not match the current TQEC version, which may cause users to lose their data.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The requirement is to ensure that the database is not overwritten without warning, and users are able to keep their existing databases.
summary.attemptedFixes: The solution proposed is to rename the database instead of overwriting it, allowing users to re-use the database with an older version of TQEC.
summary.otherNotes: The issue was raised by user nelimee, and it is related to a problem introduced in #588. The problem is that an existing database is overwritten without warning if its version does not match the current TQEC version.

issueDTO.title: Wiresystem should publish netlist changes
issueDTO.description:
Currently, the `Scene` is firing the `netlistChanged` signal.
However, the netlist is a concept implemented by the `wiresystem`. As such, the `wiresystem` should provide a callback for when the netlist changes and the `Scene` registers there and then only fires the `netlistChanged` signal when the callback gets invoked.

repository.description: A library that allows creating diagrams such as flowcharts or even proper engineering schematics within a Qt application.
repository.name: QSchematic

summary.main: The Scene is currently firing the netlistChanged signal, but the netlist is a concept implemented by the Wiresystem, so the Wiresystem should be responsible for publishing netlist changes.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The Wiresystem should provide a callback for when the netlist changes, and the Scene should register there and then only fire the netlistChanged signal when the callback gets invoked.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to the netlist changes in the Wiresystem, which should be published to the Scene, and the Scene should only fire the netlistChanged signal when the netlist changes.

issueDTO.title: CALM validate outputs incorrect line/character numbers
issueDTO.description:
## Bug Report

### Steps to Reproduce:
Run calm validate on a file with errors or warnings

Look at line numbers in report - they are not correct. This is because the input file is repeatedly converted to and from JSON objects, meaning line number info is discarded.

### Proposed fix
Every warning/error has a JSONPath reference associated with it. 
It may be simpler to simply find that JSONPath in the file and report the line/char number from there.

Failing that, we need to properly propagate the whitespace through the document as we validate it.
comments:
Suggestion for a library: https://github.com/epoberezkin/json-source-map
This builds a source map that maps jsonpaths > line/char nums

repository.description: "Architecture as Code" (AasC) aims to devise and manage software architecture via a machine readable and version-controlled codebase, fostering a robust understanding, efficient development, and seamless maintenance of complex software architectures
repository.name: architecture-as-code

summary.main:
Run calm validate on a file with errors or warnings
Look at line numbers in report - they are not correct. This is because the input file is repeatedly converted to and from JSON objects, meaning line number info is discarded.
summary.validationOrRequirement: CALM validate outputs incorrect line/character numbers
summary.attemptedFixes: Every warning/error has a JSONPath reference associated with it. It may be simpler to simply find that JSONPath in the file and report the line/char number from there.
summary.otherNotes:
Suggestion for a library: https://github.com/epoberezkin/json-source-map
This builds a source map that maps jsonpaths > line/char nums

issueDTO.title: Add integration tests to detect that the configuration is dumped in the stdout/logfile.
issueDTO.description:
Background:
GCSFuse dumps the configuration that it was started with in the log file/standard output depending upon whether it was started in background/foreground mode. We'd like to add integration tests to verify that the logging does happen.

Motivation:
Configuration logging helps determine what was the configuration of GCSFuse when it was run. It comes in handy while debugging issues.

Acceptance Criteria:
Add an integration test that should test whether the configuration is being dumped into the log file. We don't want to compare exactly whether all the flags are being written to since that'll lead to it becoming a change-detector test; we just want to know whether the dumping is happening.

doc

Always

issueDTO.title: Missing instruction for how to label clusters
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the bug

In the scenario 1 on this page, https://docs.kubestellar.io/release-0.23.0/direct/examples/#scenario-1-multi-cluster-workload-deployment-with-kubectl, new users will have a confusing time following this instruction and may encounter errors because they have not set up the correct labels for their clusters.


### Steps To Reproduce

1. Go to https://docs.kubestellar.io/release-0.23.0/direct/examples/#scenario-1-multi-cluster-workload-deployment-with-kubectl or any verison 
2. scroll to scenario 1

### Expected Behavior

There should be proper instructions for users to label their clusters so that they can successfully progress through the example. 

### Want to contribute?

- [ ] I would like to work on this issue.

### Additional Context

_No response_
comments:
@benzha14 can you offer a PR to fix this? 

```
kubectl label managedclusters cluster1 location-group=edge
kubectl label managedclusters cluster2 location-group=edge
```

(A) I think the doc structure is a little different in `main`, so look there before proceeding.

(B) There are already instructions for applying the labels, and discussion of the need for the labels. Rather than repeat that in Scenario 1 --- and Scenario 2, and Scenario 3, and so on --- perhaps a better solution is a more explicit reference to that. The current text already says the following.

> This BindingPolicy configuration determines where to deploy the workload by using the label selector expressions found in `clusterSelectors`.

Perhaps what is needed is a reminder or reference to the fact that the labeling is done in the quickstart setup and implied in the discussion at the start of the document about shell variables including the ones with label selectors that select specific clusters. Do have a look at https://docs.kubestellar.io/release-0.23.1/direct/example-scenarios/ . Perhaps the remarks about the shell variables that hold label selectors for clusters are already enough?
@MikeSpreitzer Should we redirect user to this page: https://docs.kubestellar.io/release-0.23.0/direct/example-wecs/ in case of labeling errors? Step 4 mentions labeling clusters

@benzha14: I think yes, more or less. First, the reference should be relative rather than absolute, so that it stays within the same release. Second, the example-wecs page's source is _included_ into the quickstart setup page, at https://docs.kubestellar.io/unreleased-development/direct/get-started/#create-and-register-two-workload-execution-clusters , so that is where I think the reader should be directed.

@benzha14: Please look at https://docs.kubestellar.io/unreleased-development/direct/example-scenarios/ again, particularly the first sentence in https://docs.kubestellar.io/unreleased-development/direct/example-scenarios/#assumptions-and-variables and the other remarks in that section about the label selectors, now that #2316 has merged.
ok. I'ill take a look

@MikeSpreitzer  I propose that the variables found on the end of https://docs.kubestellar.io/unreleased-development/direct/get-started/#exercise-kubestellar should be included in the beginning of scenario since it has more relevance on the same page as https://docs.kubestellar.io/unreleased-development/direct/example-scenarios/ instead of where its at currently.

if you think this is a good idea, can I go ahead and edit in the code?

@benzha14: the particular values shown in https://docs.kubestellar.io/unreleased-development/direct/get-started/#exercise-kubestellar are only correct for the setup steps done earlier in that Getting Started document. For any other setup, different values are needed in general.

@benzha14: I am concerned that putting a display in https://docs.kubestellar.io/unreleased-development/direct/example-scenarios/ that displays the settings for https://docs.kubestellar.io/unreleased-development/direct/get-started/ would be problematic because they become detached from their context, it becomes not so clear _why_ each setting is the right setting. When displayed right next to the definitions of the variables, the exhibited settings take on an air of authority that is unwarranted, and users start to suppose that the exhibited settings are the right ones in general and become hesitant to use any other values (regardless of any explicit statement that may be present).
What I have done instead is put in a link that is easy to follow. Is this good enough?
@MikeSpreitzer Its alot easier to follow now!
@MikeSpreitzer @clubanderson is it open to work

issueDTO.title: [Feature request] Allow Type Inference Without Shape Inference in ONNX
issueDTO.description:
### System information

Top of tree.

### What is the problem that this feature solves?

Currently, ONNX’s `shape_inference.infer_shapes` API performs both type and shape inference simultaneously. Type inference is guaranteed in a valid model, but shape inference is on "best effort" basis. For some operators (e.g., GridSample, Gather, Reshape, Where, etc), shape inference may fail due to incomplete or complex shape logic, even when type inference could succeed. 
This tight coupling prevents users from recovering type information when shape inference is unsupported or fails. For example, when users attempt to inject cast nodes or quantize nodes and propagate the type information downstream.


**Request:**
Please consider adding an option to ONNX’s shape inference API to:
- Run type inference independently of shape inference, so that type information can be propagated even when shape inference fails or is not implemented for an operator.
- Alternatively, relax the requirement that shape inference must succeed for type inference to run.

**Benefits:**
- Enables users and downstream tools to recover and validate type information in more models, improving robustness and usability.
- Reduces manual workarounds (such as manually setting types for affected nodes).
- Makes ONNX models more portable and easier to analyze, even when shape logic is incomplete.


### Alternatives considered

1. Create a separate function to support only type inference `infer_types` (preferable) 
2. Add boolean argument `check_shape=True` to the existing `infer_shapes` API (renaming the function is advisable in this case, `infer_shapes_and_types` or similar).


### Describe the feature

Decouple type inference from shape inference.


### Will this influence the current api (Y/N)?

Depends on the alternative selected. 
Can maintain backwards compatiblity.

### Feature Area

shape_inference

### Are you willing to contribute it (Y/N)

None

### Notes

Related issues https://github.com/onnx/onnx/issues/4934
comments: Either `types_only=False` or a new `infer_types()` sounds good to me personally. Contributions welcome!

- Run type inference independently of shape inference, so that type information can be propagated even when shape inference fails or is not implemented for an operator.
- Alternatively, relax the requirement that shape inference must succeed for type inference to run.
summary.attemptedFixes:
1. Create a separate function to support only type inference `infer_types` (preferable)
2. Add boolean argument `check_shape=True` to the existing `infer_shapes` API (renaming the function is advisable in this case, `infer_shapes_and_types` or similar)

issueDTO.title: feat: add SHA-512 hash support for SBOM formats (CycloneDX and SPDX)
issueDTO.description:
## Description

This is a feature request to add SHA-512 hash algorithm support to Trivy's SBOM parsing capabilities. Currently, Trivy only supports SHA-1, SHA-256, and MD5 hash algorithms when processing SBOM files.

Some tools, particularly NPM's SBOM generation (`npm sbom`), use SHA-512 hashes for package integrity verification. Adding SHA-512 support would enable Trivy to fully process these SBOMs and preserve important security metadata.

### Current limitations:
- **CycloneDX**: SHA-512 hashes are ignored and the hashes field becomes `null`
- **SPDX**: SHA-512 checksums are completely omitted from the output


## Current Behavior

### CycloneDX
In `pkg/sbom/cyclonedx/unmarshal.go:251-268`, the `unmarshalHashes` function only supports:
- SHA1
- SHA256
- MD5

Any other algorithm (including SHA-512) logs a warning but still creates a digest with an empty algorithm prefix (e.g., `:hashvalue` instead of `sha512:hashvalue`), resulting in malformed digest strings.

### SPDX
In `pkg/sbom/spdx/marshal.go:501-522`, the `spdxChecksums` function has the same limitation, returning `nil` for unsupported algorithms.

## Root Cause

The limitation stems from `pkg/digest/digest.go` which only defines three algorithms:
```go
const (
    SHA1   Algorithm = "sha1"
    SHA256 Algorithm = "sha256"
    MD5    Algorithm = "md5"
)
```

## Desired Behavior

Trivy should support SHA-512 hash algorithm alongside the existing SHA-1, SHA-256, and MD5 support. This would enable Trivy to:
- Preserve SHA-512 hashes when processing SBOMs from NPM and other tools
- Generate SBOMs with SHA-512 hashes when appropriate
- Maintain full compatibility with CycloneDX and SPDX specifications


## Impact

- Loss of package integrity verification data
- Generated SBOMs may be invalid or incomplete
- Affects tools that rely on SHA-512 for security validation

## Proposed Solution

1. Add SHA512 constant to `pkg/digest/digest.go`:
   ```go
   const (
       SHA1   Algorithm = "sha1"
       SHA256 Algorithm = "sha256"
       SHA512 Algorithm = "sha512"
       MD5    Algorithm = "md5"
   )
   ```

2. Add SHA-512 calculation support in the digest package

3. Update `unmarshalHashes` in CycloneDX:
   ```go
   case cdx.HashAlgoSHA512:
       alg = digest.SHA512
   ```

4. Update `spdxChecksums` in SPDX:
   ```go
   case digest.SHA512:
       alg = spdx.SHA512
   ```

## References

- NPM SBOM documentation: https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v10/commands/npm-sbom
- CycloneDX hash algorithm specification: https://cyclonedx.org/docs/1.6/json/#components_items_hashes
- SPDX checksum specification: https://spdx.github.io/spdx-spec/v2.3/package-information/#79-package-checksum-field

## Test Data

### CycloneDX Example
```json
{
  "$schema": "http://cyclonedx.org/schema/bom-1.5.schema.json",
  "bomFormat": "CycloneDX",
  "specVersion": "1.5",
  "components": [
    {
      "bom-ref": "lodash@4.17.21",
      "type": "library",
      "name": "lodash",
      "version": "4.17.21",
      "hashes": [
        {
          "alg": "SHA-512",
          "content": "bf690311ee7b95e713ba568322e3533f2dd1cb880b189e99d4edef13592b81764daec43e2c54c61d5c558dc5cfb35ecb85b65519e74026ff17675b6f8f916f4a"
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}
```

### SPDX Example
```json
{
  "spdxVersion": "SPDX-2.3",
  "packages": [
    {
      "name": "lodash",
      "SPDXID": "SPDXRef-Package-lodash-4.17.21",
      "checksums": [
        {
          "algorithm": "SHA512",
          "checksumValue": "bf690311ee7b95e713ba568322e3533f2dd1cb880b189e99d4edef13592b81764daec43e2c54c61d5c558dc5cfb35ecb85b65519e74026ff17675b6f8f916f4a"
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}
```

### Discussed in https://github.com/aquasecurity/trivy/discussions/9082
comments:

> hi, im interested in this issue, can i take it?, and also is there anything you'd like to see or avoid? thanks!

However, since we want to include it in the next release, if you cannot make it this month, we may ask someone else to take care of it.

issueDTO.title: Make `run` cmd in CLI print a list of collected errors
issueDTO.description:
Right now, when `lingo.dev run` command fails, it prints something like this:

```
[Localization]
✓ Localization engine ready (Lingo.dev)
✓ Processing localization tasks (tasks: 2, concurrency: 2)
 
[Done]
• 0 from cache
• 0 processed
• 2 failed
```

When N(failed) > 0, I want us to show `[Errors]` section that prints a list of issues.

Design notes:
- Must follow the same styling - `[Errors]` must be orange, like the rest of the title
- Every error must use "x" icon painted in red as its bullet point mark
- The error message color must be regular white

issueDTO.title: Link menu button in lists
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**
When a list entry contains only a link, the three-dot menu button to switch between text and preview is displayed left to it. The alignment is off and overlaps the menu bullet point:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ab7f5c4a-9482-470a-870e-e2ce138bbfa3)

But probably we should not show the menu at all in lists, as switching a link to preview breaks the entire list.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Add a standalone text link inside a link item
2. See the broken alignment of the three-dot menu button
3. Opne three-dot menu and select 'preview'
4. See broken list

**Expected behavior**
Either disable the menu to switch between text and preview link inside lists, or fix both showing previews in lists and alignment of the button in lists.

**Server details:**
- Nextcloud version: 29

issueDTO.title: Detect declared-only instance attributes
issueDTO.description:
### Summary

When typing unit tests written with `pytest`, when parametrizing a fixture in the following way:

```python
# /// script
# dependencies = [
#   "pytest",
# ]
# ///

import pytest


@pytest.fixture(params=["foo", "bar"])
def foo_fixture(request: pytest.FixtureRequest) -> str:
    return request.param
```

`ty` does not recognize that the `pytest.FixtureRequest` object does indeed have a `param` attribute:

```shell
uvx ty check .
error[unresolved-attribute]: Type `FixtureRequest` has no attribute `param`
  --> main.py:12:12
   |
10 | @pytest.fixture(params=["foo", "bar"])
11 | def foo_fixture(request: pytest.FixtureRequest) -> str:
12 |     return request.param
   |            ^^^^^^^^^^^^^
   |
info: rule `unresolved-attribute` is enabled by default
```

despite the fact that `pytest.FixtureRequest` declares this attribute in it's `__init__` method:

```python
class FixtureRequest(abc.ABC):
    """The type of the ``request`` fixture.

    A request object gives access to the requesting test context and has a
    ``param`` attribute in case the fixture is parametrized.
    """

    def __init__(
        self,
        pyfuncitem: Function,
        fixturename: str | None,
        arg2fixturedefs: dict[str, Sequence[FixtureDef[Any]]],
        fixture_defs: dict[str, FixtureDef[Any]],
        *,
        _ispytest: bool = False,
    ) -> None:
        check_ispytest(_ispytest)
        #: Fixture for which this request is being performed.
        self.fixturename: Final = fixturename
        self._pyfuncitem: Final = pyfuncitem
        # The FixtureDefs for each fixture name requested by this item.
        # Starts from the statically-known fixturedefs resolved during
        # collection. Dynamically requested fixtures (using
        # `request.getfixturevalue("foo")`) are added dynamically.
        self._arg2fixturedefs: Final = arg2fixturedefs
        # The evaluated argnames so far, mapping to the FixtureDef they resolved
        # to.
        self._fixture_defs: Final = fixture_defs
        # Notes on the type of `param`:
        # -`request.param` is only defined in parametrized fixtures, and will raise
        #   AttributeError otherwise. Python typing has no notion of "undefined", so
        #   this cannot be reflected in the type.
        # - Technically `param` is only (possibly) defined on SubRequest, not
        #   FixtureRequest, but the typing of that is still in flux so this cheats.
        # - In the future we might consider using a generic for the param type, but
        #   for now just using Any.
        self.param: Any

    ...
```

Both `mypy` and `pyright` do not emit an error for this (`mypy` does complain about the return annotation being a `str` and `request.param` returning `Any` in strict mode, though).

I guess that attributes assigned in `__init__` methods are currently not considered or that there is at least no proper resolution to which `__init__` gets called (since this is an ABC)? The comment above `self.param` may also be relevant here.

### Version

ty 0.0.1-alpha.11
comments:
Thank you very much for reporting this — and for the initial analysis.

We're currently not recognizing a declaration-only annotated assignment (without a right-hand side) such as `self.param: Type` as evidence for an instance attribute:
```py
class C:
    def __init__(self):
        self.a: int


C().a  # unresolved-attribute
```
https://play.ty.dev/812a2e90-7b5f-4865-a3d6-daad7fa6a4bf

This is a known limitation (see the `TODO` for `declared_only` in [this test case](https://github.com/astral-sh/ruff/blob/cb152b47253182df9bbd19a93a700e90060774cb/crates/ty_python_semantic/resources/mdtest/attributes.md#variable-only-declaredbound-in-__init__)).
Looks interesting. I will take a look this/next week. @sharkdp If I have any questions regarding the PR should I post them here?
@iyakushev Sounds great. Feel free to post questions here or on our [Discord channel](https://discord.com/invite/astral-sh) in `#typing`.

summary.main: The issue is about detecting declared-only instance attributes in Python. When typing unit tests written with `pytest`, when parametrizing a fixture in the following way, `ty` does not recognize that the `pytest.FixtureRequest` object does indeed have a `param` attribute.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue is that `ty` does not recognize the `param` attribute of `pytest.FixtureRequest` object, even though it is declared in the `__init__` method. This is a known limitation in `ty`.
summary.attemptedFixes: The patch provided in the comments switches everything from bindings-only to declarations-only, which would fix the issue. However, this needs to be extended to consider both bindings and declarations. The comment also mentions that declarations should take precedence over bindings, and that even if there are conflicting definitions, the type of the attribute should be determined by the declaration.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is about detecting declared-only instance attributes in Python. The issue is that `ty` does not recognize the `param` attribute of `pytest.FixtureRequest` object, even though it is declared in the `__init__` method. The comment above `self.param` mentions that `param` is only defined in parametrized fixtures and will raise AttributeError otherwise. The issue is also mentioned in the `TODO` for `declared_only` in the `attributes.md` file.

issueDTO.title: [FEATURE] <Social Sharing Buttons on Blogs>
issueDTO.description:
### Why do we need this improvement?

Currently, the website lacks a mechanism for users to easily share blog posts on social media platforms. This limits the reach and visibility of the content, making it harder for readers to promote the blogs organically to a broader audience.

### How will this change help?

This change will ease the sharing of blog amongst social platforms.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### How could it be implemented/designed?

Add social sharing buttons to each blog post. These buttons should allow users to share the post on popular platforms such as:

    Twitter
    LinkedIn

Each button should generate a pre-filled sharing link, including the blog post title, URL, and possibly hashtags. For example:

```Twitter: https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Check+out+this+blog!&url=https://www.asyncapi.com/blog/2024-annual-summary#social-media```

The buttons should be visually appealing, lightweight, and non-intrusive. They can be displayed at the top or bottom of each blog post.

### 🚧 Breaking changes

Yes

### 👀 Have you checked for similar open issues?

- [x] I checked and didn't find a similar issue

### 🏢 Have you read the Contributing Guidelines?

- [x] I have read the [Contributing Guidelines](https://github.com/asyncapi/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)

issueDTO.title: Refactoring for Unit Test Access Controls
issueDTO.description:
Part of #12048

## Issue
After most of the Unit Test migration in #12048, there are a lot of inconsistencies in access control test methods. This is because we did not migrate the many convenient, abstracted, and commonly used access control test methods from `ui/webapi/BaseActionTest.java` to `sqlui/webapi/BaseActionTest.java`.

After merging #13254, all of the access control test methods in `BaseActionTest.java` have been migrated. Hence, this issue aims to refactor the unit test access controls to use these convenient test methods.

## Progress
The progress for this refactoring can be found [here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1IcB-viJMrIOknYoBYasBuRBK9qnwY0-doEK4_Eb24IA/edit?gid=0#gid=0). I (the author) will update it when completed PRs are merged proactively.

## Steps to Contribute

1. Choose test(s) to work on in the above Google Sheets link
2. Check that no on else have claimed the test cases to work on within the last 2 weeks, or that it has been completed by follow up PRs (but not updated in the sheets)
3. Comment on this issue to indicate that you'd like to contribute on the chosen test(s). Update your comment if you need more than 2 weeks so that other contributors don't overlap with your work.
4. Create a PR to refactor the unit test(s).
5. Submit the PR, with a link to this issue by starting the description with "Part of #13304"## Tips

- Understand the access control test methods in `sqlui/webapi/BaseActionTest.java`, follow the refactoring in #13254
- Most of the access control testing logic in the migrated unit tests under `sqlui/webapi` follows the old unit tests under `ui/webapi`, so you may wish to reference the old unit test for help

  This issue is for **first-time contributors only**. If you are new to TEAMMATES, feel free to submit a PR for this issue.

**We do not assign issues to contributors**. If you would like to pick up this issue, do post a comment below to express your interest and check if there is anyone else who is already working on the issue. We will do our best to reply and give you the go-ahead, but if we don't, feel free to submit a PR as long as there is no one else working on it.

**To get started**, do read through our [contributing guidelines](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/contributing-doc.html) carefully, and [set up a development environment on your local machine](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/setting-up.html) before making a PR.

If you need any clarifications on our [developer guide](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/index.html), or are facing issues that are not found in our [troubleshooting guide](https://teammates.github.io/teammates/troubleshooting-guide.html), please [post a message in our discussion forum](https://github.com/TEAMMATES/teammates/discussions).

issueDTO.title: docs(`isEmpty`): mention that `null` is not accepted as input
issueDTO.description:
```
> R.isEmpty(null)
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot convert undefined or null to object
    at Function.keys (<anonymous>)
    at Module.Wo (chunk-4DPIFY6Y.js:1:127)
    at <anonymous>:1:3
```
comments: isEmpty does not accept `null` as an input.
Could isEmpty be updated to accept null as an input? If not, what is the motivation?

`null` is not a container and has no concept of being empty. Returning `false` for `isEmpty(null)` would be expected, but it's not the only **semantically correct** result. It's easy to do `isEmpty(x ?? [])` or even `x === null || isEmpty(x)` if that's the logic you need, but someone else might want to handle `null`s differently.

In Remeda, we prefer the input types be as strict as possible so that you get compile-time errors if a change upstream causes a mismatching type.

Similarly, you wouldn't expect `map(null, ...)` to return an empty array, which means that `null` isn't the equivalent of an empty array everywhere, creating inconsistency in the API.

> isEmpty does not accept `null` as an input.

This should be added to the docs IMO
i think it's fair to add it to the docs, considering that `undefined` gets a mention. i'll reopen and rename the ticket
It's worth mentioning that on the other hand `R.isEmpty(undefined)` returns true. (In that, it seems a little inconsistent to accept one but not the other)

> In Remeda, we prefer the input types be as strict as possible so that you get compile-time errors if a change upstream causes a mismatching type.

I agree with this, but there can be unexpected cases (like human errors), that can make the input be null. In this case, it will throw a runtime error, which is unpleasant.

What if a default error handling is added instead? Add a `try..catch` block that will return `true` on error.

repository.description: A utility library for JavaScript and TypeScript.
repository.name: remeda

summary.main: The issue is about adding a note to the `isEmpty` documentation stating that `null` is not accepted as input. The discussion highlights the importance of strict input types in Remeda and the potential for runtime errors if `null` is passed as an input.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The requirement is to mention that `null` is not accepted as input in the `isEmpty` documentation. The discussion emphasizes the importance of strict input types in Remeda and the potential for runtime errors if `null` is passed as an input.
summary.attemptedFixes: One contributor provided a custom implementation of `isEmpty` that handles `null` as an input, while another suggested adding a `try..catch` block to return `true` on error. However, the discussion ultimately concludes that Remeda should maintain its strict input types and not attempt to handle unexpected cases like `null` inputs.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about mentioning that `null` is not accepted as input in the `isEmpty` documentation. The discussion highlights the importance of strict input types in Remeda and the potential for runtime errors if `null` is passed as an input. Some contributors suggest adding a default error handling mechanism, but others argue that Remeda is not designed to address typing issues in projects.

issueDTO.title: Replace usage of Nominatim with pg-nearest-city
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

- Nominatim is a great web reverse geocoder, hosted for free by OSM.
- We don't need detailed reverse geocoding to an address. Instead projects can be reverse geocoded to the nearest city of 1000 people.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

- We made a package for FieldTM to do exactly that: github.com/hotosm/pg-nearest-city/
- Using the underlying PostGIS database, we can reverse geocode during project creation, entirely offline.
- Usage of Nominatim can be removed, also reducing the load on the OSM-hosted server during testing / project creation.
comments:
I think there are some inconsistencies between using nominatim and pg-nearest-city library. 

- In the boundary area, while nominatim provides correct country name, pg-nearest-city may sometime show incorrect country. For example, While we create project on Field-TM for Suryodaya municipality, which lies near the border, the project showed different country. However, creating project with same AOI on tasking manager, which use nominatim, shows correct country name. 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3b9b4760-10a6-489b-bde8-89a189d0c983)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1fc1a135-e629-4a03-abe1-222b56def46f)

Thats a really interesting point!

Is the AOI geographically closer to Shri Antu, Nepal than to Mirik, India?

We can solve this - thanks for pointing out - its literally matching to the closest city of 1000 people, disregarding country borders (when we should probably respect country borders as higher priority)
I am not sure of the geographic proximity but I agree country borders should be high in order.

Also the country naming differs from Nominatim (for example: U.S and United States).Since the filters and charts use the Nominatim name, If we plan to integrate it, we'll need to run a script on the production database to update the names accordingly and also make other api and frontend changes too i suppose. It would be great if we can maintain the same naming convention too if possible.

> Also the country naming differs from Nominatim (for example: U.S and United States).Since the filters and charts use the Nominatim name, If we plan to integrate it, we'll need to run a script on the production database to update the names accordingly and also make other api and frontend changes too i suppose. It would be great if we can maintain the same naming convention too if possible.

Thanks for the info!

Ideally we would use country iso codes for filters etc, rather than strings like this, avoiding this problem. I wonder if that would be possible (maybe needs db changes, like you say).

Either way, we have an intern starting for a few weeks that may be able to dig into these things for pg-nearest-city. Should we re-assign? 🙏
